bestBHT.bht: The Corinthians were urged to hold fast to the gospel message they had received, for it was not just a matter of belief, but held the power to save them. Their salvation depended on faithfully retaining and remembering the teachings they had received, even in the face of opposition or doubt. If they were to let go of this truth, their faith would be in vain and their profession empty. They needed to understand that true salvation required a steadfast belief in Christ's resurrection and a commitment to the gospel's message.

Henry Alford: which ye also received, in which moreover ye stand, by means of which ye are even being saved (in the course of salvation)."
The only chance if you hold fast what I have taught you, of your missing salvation, is the hardly supposable one, that your faith is vain, and the gospel a fable.
unless ye believed (not as A.V. 'have believed,' which confuses the idea: it is, 'became believers') in vain.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: If ye hold fast (in memory and personal appropriation) with what speech I preached it unto you.
Your faith is vain, in resting on Christ's resurrection as an objective reality.
Albert Barnes: By which also ye are saved...It does not mean simply that by this they were brought into a salvable state...but it means that their hopes of eternal life rested on this; and by this they were then 'in fact' saved from the condemnation of sin, and were in the possession of the hope of eternal life.

If ye keep in memory...the idea is, that they were saved by this, or would be, if they faithfully retained or held the doctrine as he delivered it; if they observed it, and still believed it, notwithstanding all the efforts of their enemies, and all the arts of false teaching to wrest it from them.

Unless ye have believed in vain...Unless all your trials, discouragements, and hopes were to no purpose, and all have been the result of imposture; and unless all your profession is false and hollow, you will be saved by this great doctrine which I first preached to you.
Marvin Vincent: I see no good reason for departing from the arrangement of the A. V., which states that the salvation of the readers depends on their holding fast the word preached."
This is certainly very awkward, making Paul say that their holding it fast was the condition on which he preached it."
John Calvin: In the first, he reproves their carelessness or fickleness, because such a sudden fall was an evidence that they had never understood what had been delivered to them, or that their knowledge of it had been loose and floating, inasmuch as it had so quickly vanished.
By the second, he warns them that they had needlessly and uselessly professed allegiance to Christ if they did not hold fast this main doctrine.
To believe in vain, according to the use of ancient languages, is to believe without just reason and authority, giving credit to idle reports as true and authentic.
Archibald T. Robertson: In what words I preached it unto you... it is not clear whether the clause depends on γνωριζω like the other relatives, but most likely so."
Paul assumes that they are holding it fast."
Condition of first class, unless in fact ye did believe to no purpose.
John Gill: Salvation is inseparably connected with true faith in Christ as a Saviour, and with a hearty belief of his resurrection from the dead."
To which the apostle puts in the following provisos and exceptions; the one is, if ye keep in memory what I preached unto you."
It is the man that perseveres in the faith and doctrine of Christ that shall be saved.
John Wesley: Your salvation is begun, and will be perfected, if ye continue in the faith.
Unless indeed your faith was only a delusion.
Unless ye have believed in vain.

bhtAttempts.bht: The Corinthians had received and stood firm in the gospel message, which was not just words, but the means by which salvation was being worked out in their lives. However, there was a possibility that their faith was empty and the gospel they had believed in was a mere fiction. The condition for their salvation was to hold fast to the message that was preached to them, to remember and retain it despite any opposition. Their hopes of eternal life hinged on this doctrine, and if they did not hold onto it, their belief would be in vain, rendering their profession false and hollow. It was essential for them to understand that true faith in Christ and belief in His resurrection were integral to salvation.

The Corinthians had received and stood firm in the gospel message, which was not just words, but the means by which salvation was being worked out in their lives. However, there was a possibility that their faith was empty and the gospel they had believed in was a mere fiction. The condition for their salvation was to hold fast to the message that was preached to them, to remember and retain it despite any opposition. Their hopes of eternal life hinged on this doctrine, and if they did not hold onto it, their belief would be in vain, rendering their profession false and hollow.

The Corinthians were advised to hold fast to the gospel message they had received, which was crucial for their salvation. If they let go of this truth, their faith in Christ's resurrection would be in vain, and their profession of faith would be empty and without purpose. They were exhorted to remember and retain the teachings that were passed on to them, despite any challenges or temptations to abandon them. True salvation depended on their sincere belief and unwavering commitment to the gospel.

The Corinthians were urged to hold fast to the gospel message they had received, for it was not just a matter of belief, but held the power to save them. Their salvation depended on faithfully retaining and remembering the teachings they had received, even in the face of opposition or doubt. If they were to let go of this truth, their faith would be in vain and their profession empty. They needed to understand that true salvation required a steadfast belief in Christ's resurrection and a commitment to the gospel's message.

The Corinthians were warned that their salvation rested on their unwavering commitment to the gospel they had received. If they failed to hold fast to the message, their faith would be in vain and their profession of belief futile. It was crucial that they remember and retain the teachings they had been given, even in the face of opposition. True salvation hinged on their sincere belief in Christ's resurrection and their steadfast adherence to the gospel's truth.
